sense.name: (cause to) gain a characteristic or attribute
sense.commentary: Note: GET may be substitute with BECOME for most of these instances NP GET ADJP[attribute]--for the following expressions only! Includes: GET DRESSED, GET STUCK, GET WELL, GET WORSE, GET EVEN--meaning "equalize" not "take revenge"
sense.examples: Then I got dressed and looked at myself in the mirror. Rush out of bed to get the kids dressed, let the cat out, get your partner's lunch ready. This picture was taken before the elevator got stuck with doors open. Get well soon! Just when I thought things couldn't get worse, they did. Seattle got even early in the second quarter.

sense.name: (cause to) attain a state/location relative to a point of reference
sense.commentary: Includes: GET ACROSS, GET AHEAD, GET AWAY, GET BEHIND, GET BACK, GET BY, GET DOWN, GET IN, GET INTO, GET OFF, GET ON, GET OUT, GET OVER, GET THROUGH, GET TO, GET UP Syntax Is: NP1 GET PP{P NP[location]} Note: may be used metaphorically
sense.examples: I got across the river last night as wet as a drowned rat. We got across 500 miles in a mere 8 or so hours. Tired, confused crew members got ahead of the fire and uphill from it. I think we just got ahead of ourselves and didn't get clear enough thinking. How to get away from your lover on Valentine`s Day. I moved across the car to get away from the door. These horsemen got behind the ridge on our right again. I just got back from the dentist. Bride's Biscuit got by the other dogs to win the race. What time did you get in? Get out your best dress, we're going dancing. The rain clouds can't get over the mountain. Hey, if I hang up my cell phone I'll get to work in time. I can't take it anymore, I have to get away! He reined up his horse and got down. She opened the door and told him to get in. Don't be afraid of the horse, just get on. Get out! I've fallen and I can't get up.

sense.name: enter into activity, begin
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1 GET [predicate] Includes: GET CRACKING, GET DOWN, GET GOING, GET MOVING, GET OFF, GET ROLLING, GET STARTED, GET TO, GET WEAVING
sense.examples: To fix these problems you folks with the source code for this puppy need to get cracking. Kate and Sawyer got down to business in the fish-biscuit cage. He'll get going on a good rant, throw in a few smart things, and suddenly you're convinced. Let's get moving on this tutorial. They got off to a good start. It's up to the city to get ball rolling. You must serve participants as soon as you can get the project rolling. And don't get me started on our wacko teetotalism! Agendas allow social people to recognize when it is time to get to business. Bring on the fisticuffs and let's get weaving.

sense.name: travel, move about
sense.commentary: Includes: GET ABOUT, GET AROUND, GET OUT
sense.examples: Getting about in Bangkok has traditionally been a bit of a challenge. We marveled at our doggie's ability to get around on just three legs. Anywho, so news gets around that Jeff and I can't find our way to the Holiday Inn. Coast to coast the word got out: Don't go see 'Gigli.'

sense.name: progress, advance
sense.commentary: Includes: GET AHEAD, GET ALONG, GET ON Note: compare carefully to sense 2; here, there is no point of reference
sense.examples: Wanna get ahead in love and life? It seems he's getting more outspoken as he's getting along in his career. She did not count her birthdays or worry because she was getting on in years. How are you getting along in your new place? It's getting on midnight--let's all go to bed.

sense.name: reach, arrive at (concrete or abstract)
sense.commentary: Includes: GET AROUND TO (abstractly), GET AT, GET TO
sense.examples: He never got to first base with any of his big wheels and deals. He finally got around to painting the windows. That's the closest some of us ever get to setting goals. I cannot get at the postman (I cannot even see him to give him my ferocious appearance.) Can you get at the stuff inside?

sense.name: finish, reach the end of
sense.examples: Let's get this job over with. This tagging task is such a pain, I don't know how I'll get through it! I was so weak that I could not get through a day without taking a nap.

sense.name: become aware of
sense.commentary: Includes: GET A LINE, GET WIND, GET WORD
sense.examples: Be informed--get a line on new bankruptcy ramifications. When the townswomen get wind of the scheme, they invite some Spanish fishermen to the same dance. We will be working time and half to bring you all the details as we get word of them.

sense.name: perceive through one of the senses
sense.commentary: Includes: GET A LOAD, GET A LOOK, GET A NOSEFUL, GET A WHIFF
sense.examples: Through those thin walls we really got a load of their fight. I just got a look inside and it's impressive. I knew we were in trouble when I opened up the noodle box and got a noseful of that Heinz tomato smell. Get a whiff of the new pot sniffing technologies, coming to a highway near you.

sense.name: contact, reach, communicate with
sense.commentary: Includes: GET HOLD OF, GET IN TOUCH, GET THROUGH
sense.examples: I think there was about 3 years where even my family couldn't get a hold of me. How do I get in touch with the person who filed the complaint? Get in touch with your inner rodent. I got through to tech support on my first attempt.

sense.name: communicate a meaning
sense.examples: I couldn't get across the message. Even though my point got across, it was dismissed as inconsequential. The safety message has definitely got through to young people. I'm hoping he'll get through to his minions to curb their enthusiasm.

sense.name: understand
sense.commentary: Includes: GET IT, GET ONTO, GET THE PICTURE, GET WISE
sense.examples: Changing names of entries confused some, but they got it eventually. It took her a little bit of time to get onto the idea that I wanted to transfer. I explained it a dozen times, but he still doesn't get the picture. And yes, we finally got wise to the dust problem, and covered the couches.

sense.name: have good relations
sense.commentary: Includes: GET ALONG, GET ALONG WITH, GET ON, GET ON WITH
sense.examples: Can't we all just get along? I never really got along with art teachers. He often comes to see us, and he and Mamma get on very well together. And it made me wonder why people just can't get on with each other.

sense.name: have sexual relations
sense.commentary: Includes: GET AROUND, GET IT ON, GET LAID
sense.examples: He has a different girlfriend every week, he really gets around. They are having the pandas watch videos of other pandas getting it on. Married folk get laid most, this unsurprising sex study reveals.

sense.name: enter into marriage
sense.examples: Throughout the ages, the royals got hitched for duty (and money), not love. Before you get married, answer these important questions with your partner.

sense.name: affect
sense.commentary: Includes: GET AT, GET DOWN, GET HOLD OF, GET TO
sense.examples: If you really want to get at him, beat his score one day and he'll sulk for a week! Rainy days and Mondays always get me down. Once an idea gets hold of me, I can keep writing hour after hour. They used blackmail to get at the former finance minister. There is just something about the blues that really gets to me.

sense.name: regain, recover
sense.examples: I need to now set up regular writing schedules to get my groove back! How can I get my money back? Someone help me get my feet back on the ground.

sense.name: take revenge
sense.examples: The article discribes using tarpits to get back at spammers. They're my mother's curse to get back at me for the things that I did when I was a child! Don't get mad, get even.

sense.name: avoid unpleasant situations or consequences
sense.commentary: Includes: GET AROUND, GET AWAY, GET OFF, GET OUT, GET BY
sense.examples: Is there any way to get around this problem? Her parents let her get away with murder! The lawyer got him off despite the evidence. You got off lightly this time. My sister always got out of doing the dishes. How did he get by with that sort of thing?

sense.name: cope, manage, make do
sense.examples: If you had any ambition, you'd go out and find some work, and everybody got by. Somehow I manage to get by without idle chit-chat with strangers.

sense.name: swallow, ingest
sense.examples: He got down a few bites of the turkey.

sense.name: put in writing
sense.examples: Please say that again so that I can get it all down. I was writing as fast as I could and I got down that we can improve data validation

sense.name: obtain
sense.examples: Does anyone know where in the UK I can get hold of banana leafs?

sense.name: enter a realm, become involved with
sense.examples: Harvard sent her a letter yesterday telling her she got in. I got in on a great deal and don't want to lose it. The more we got into their inner circle of trust, the more we kept discovering. She got into drugs when she was in college. How did you get into this field?

sense.name: submit, send to
sense.examples: Did you get your paper in on time? Get the check off to them today!

sense.name: thoroughly enjoy
sense.examples: I never really got into hockey until I went to a few games. She gets off on buying shoes.

sense.name: receive punishment
sense.commentary: Includes: GET IT, GET ONE'S LUMPS
sense.examples: Oooh, now you're gonna get it! Napoleon got his lumps at Waterloo.

sense.name: be temporarily relieved of one's duties
sense.examples: I get off work at seven.

sense.name: be stoned, drugged, high
sense.examples: He gets high every weekend. She's a white woman who gets off on just about any drug.

sense.name: deliver verbally
sense.examples: He got off the best line I've heard in a long time. I managed to get out a few words.

sense.name: overcome
sense.examples: I finally got over that cold. He got over his shyness and asked her out. Oh, just get over it!

sense.name: assemble, join forces, gather together
sense.examples: Get together all those who are interested in the project. The soprano and the pianist did not get together for this piece. Fitness experts got together with a great commitment to promote exercise.

sense.name: awake, wake up
sense.examples: The baby still gets us up in the middle of the night. We get up at 5 a.m. during the week.

sense.name: develop, produce
sense.examples: Twain asked "Can't you get up a plot for a 'skeleton novelette'? But if you want to get up an appetite just stroll over the mountains all day. Even though we're short-handed, we can get out a dozen cakes a day.

sense.name: dress up
sense.examples: She got herself up in a bizarre outfit. The princess, got up in all her finery, was led to the well.

sense.name: study intensively
sense.examples: (no examples found, only reference in WordNet)

sense.name: idiomatic expressions
sense.commentary: Includes: GET OFF THE GROUND, GET THE BEST, GET THE BETTER OF, GET THE GOODS, GET THE HANG, GET THE JUMP, GET RID OF, GET TO GRIPS, GET UNDER ONE'S SKIN
